Claude Code API Request Analysis

Analyzing how Claude Code communicates with inference servers via the Anthropic Messages API.

Experiment Overview

This dashboard visualizes raw API request bodies captured from Claude Code sessions routed through a local llama serve proxy. The goal is to understand the structure, size, and multi-turn patterns of Claude Code's API requests — comparing a fully configured environment (plugins, global settings, MCP servers) against a vanilla installation.

Hardware

  • Machine: MacBook Pro, Apple M3 Max
  • Memory: 36 GB unified
  • OS: macOS Sequoia 15.4

Software

  • Model: Qwen 3.5 35B (Q4_K_M, 20.1 GB)
  • Backend: llama.cpp (llama-server)
  • Proxy: llama serve (--log-dir for body dumps)
  • Client: Claude Code (headless, -p mode)

Test Setup

  • NORMAL: Full user config — global CLAUDE.md, plugins (oh-my-claudecode, etc.), MCP servers
  • CLEAN: Vanilla Claude Code — HOME=/tmp/claude-clean override, no plugins or custom settings
  • Server restart between each test for KV cache fairness

Test Prompts

  • hello: Write a python script that prints 'hello world', save as hello.py, then execute it
  • fibonacci: Write a python script that prints fibonacci (1st-50th), save as fib.py, then execute it
  • fastapi: Write a simple FastAPI app with GET / and GET /health endpoints, save as app.py

Key Findings

Request size: Normal avg 138 KB vs Clean avg 95 KB per request. Tools account for 62% of total payload (85.9 KB in normal, 61.1 KB in clean).
Latency: Normal avg 123.3s vs Clean avg 76.5s (+46.7s, 38% slower). The slowdown is disproportionate to the size increase — complex system instructions appear to increase thinking/reasoning time.
Multi-turn overhead: Each agentic turn re-sends the full conversation history (system + tools + all prior messages). A 6-turn session sends the 85 KB tools payload 6 times.
Internal calls: Claude Code makes lightweight claude-haiku sub-calls for tool result summarization and title generation. These are ~1.7 KB each with no tools attached.

Select a session from the sidebar to inspect individual API requests.
